questions.question: Why did the British rulers start planning to give independence to India?
questions.answer: During the Second World War the freedom struggle in India became very strong. The people demanded complete independence. The British government realised that it was difficult to control India any more. Therefore they began planning to transfer power to Indians.

questions.question: Why was the Muslim League established?
questions.answer: The British followed the policy of divide and rule in India. They encouraged the formation of the Muslim League to divide Hindus and Muslims. This organisation spread communal ideas. As a result national unity was weakened.

questions.question: What was the Two Nation Theory?
questions.answer: The Two Nation Theory was given by Muhammad Ali Jinnah. It stated that Hindus and Muslims were two separate nations. According to this idea Muslims needed a separate country. This led to the demand for Pakistan.

questions.question: Why did the Wavell Plan fail?
questions.answer: The Wavell Plan suggested equal Hindu and Muslim members in the Executive Council. Jinnah insisted that only Muslim League could nominate Muslim members. The Congress opposed this demand. Therefore the plan failed.

questions.question: What was the Cabinet Mission?
questions.answer: In March 1946 three British ministers came to India. They were Pethick Lawrence, Stafford Cripps and A.V. Alexander. They discussed plans for independence with Indian leaders. This delegation was called the Cabinet Mission.

questions.question: What was Direct Action Day?
questions.answer: Direct Action Day was observed on 16 August 1946. It was declared by the Muslim League. It led to severe communal riots in many parts of the country. Thousands of people were killed in violence.

questions.question: What was the Interim Government?
questions.answer: The Interim Government was formed by the British in 1946. Jawaharlal Nehru became its head. The Muslim League first refused to join it. Later they joined but the government could not function smoothly.

questions.question: What was the Mountbatten Plan?
questions.answer: The Mountbatten Plan was announced in 1947. It decided the partition of India into two nations. India and Pakistan were created as separate countries. It also fixed the date for independence.

questions.question: What is meant by the Partition of India?
questions.answer: Partition means the division of India into India and Pakistan. It took place in August 1947. Punjab and Bengal were divided between the two countries. This caused mass migration and violence.

questions.question: What problems were faced due to partition?
questions.answer: Partition caused large scale riots and killings. Millions of people became refugees. Families were separated and lost their homes. It created deep communal hatred.

questions.question: What was the refugee problem after independence?
questions.answer: After partition millions of people were forced to leave their homes. Hindus and Sikhs came to India while Muslims went to Pakistan. They lived in camps without food or shelter. The government had to resettle them.

questions.question: What role did Mahatma Gandhi play after partition?
questions.answer: Gandhiji tried to stop communal violence. He visited riot affected areas. He fasted to bring peace between Hindus and Muslims. His efforts reduced hatred among people.

questions.question: Who was Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel?
questions.answer: Sardar Patel was a great leader of independent India. He is known as the Iron Man of India. He played a key role in integrating princely states. He worked for national unity.

questions.question: What were princely states?
questions.answer: Princely states were small kingdoms in British India. They were ruled by local kings. They were not directly under British rule. After independence they had to join India.

questions.question: What was the Instrument of Accession?
questions.answer: It was a legal document signed by rulers of princely states. By signing it they agreed to join India. Most states accepted it. This helped unite the country.

questions.question: What was Operation Polo?
questions.answer: Operation Polo was a military action in 1948. It was used to merge Hyderabad with India. The Nizam refused to join India. The operation succeeded within few days.

questions.question: Why was the integration of princely states difficult?
questions.answer: There were 565 princely states in India. Some rulers wanted independence. Some wanted to join Pakistan. It was a big challenge for the Indian government.

questions.question: What was the problem of Junagadh?
questions.answer: Junagadh was a Hindu majority state ruled by a Muslim king. The ruler wanted to join Pakistan. People opposed this decision. Finally Junagadh was merged with India.

questions.question: Why was Kashmir a problem?
questions.answer: Kashmir had a Muslim majority ruled by a Hindu king. The ruler delayed joining India. Pakistan attacked Kashmir. Finally Kashmir joined India through Instrument of Accession.

questions.question: Who was Jawaharlal Nehru?
questions.answer: Jawaharlal Nehru was the first Prime Minister of India. He gave the famous Tryst with Destiny speech. He worked for democracy and development. He helped build modern India.

questions.question: What is national integration?
questions.answer: National integration means unity of the nation. It brings people of different regions together. Sardar Patel played a major role in it. It strengthens the country.

questions.question: What difficulties did India face after independence?
questions.answer: India faced refugee problems and food shortage. There was communal violence. Princely states had to be integrated. The economy was also very weak.

questions.question: Why is Sardar Patel called the Iron Man of India?
questions.answer: Sardar Patel firmly united all princely states. He did not allow any state to remain separate. He used diplomacy and force when needed. Therefore he is called the Iron Man.

questions.question: What was the role of the Red Cross after partition?
questions.answer: The Red Cross helped refugees after partition. It provided food, clothes and medicines. It set up relief camps. It helped people who lost their homes.

questions.question: What happened in Noakhali?
questions.answer: Noakhali witnessed severe communal riots in 1946. Many Hindus were attacked. Gandhiji visited the area to restore peace. His efforts reduced violence.

questions.question: Why did millions of people migrate in 1947?
questions.answer: India was divided into India and Pakistan. People moved according to religion. Hindus and Sikhs came to India. Muslims went to Pakistan.

questions.question: What was the main aim of independent India?
questions.answer: The main aim was to build a strong and united nation. The leaders wanted peace and development. They wanted social equality. Democracy was also promoted.

questions.question: How did partition affect families?
questions.answer: Families were separated during migration. Many lost their relatives. People left behind their homes and property. It caused great suffering.

questions.question: What steps were taken to resettle refugees?
questions.answer: The government opened relief camps. Food, clothes and shelter were provided. New colonies were built. Refugees were given jobs and land.

questions.question: Why is 15 August 1947 important?
questions.answer: On this day India became independent. British rule ended in India. Jawaharlal Nehru became the Prime Minister. It is celebrated as Independence Day.

questions.question: What was the role of the Indian National Congress after independence?
questions.answer: The Congress formed the first government of independent India. It focused on rebuilding the nation. It worked to maintain unity and democracy. It also started development programmes.

questions.question: What was the impact of independence on Indian society?
questions.answer: Independence ended British rule in India. Indians felt proud and free. People got democratic rights. It also created responsibility to build the nation.

questions.question: Why was national unity necessary after independence?
questions.answer: India was divided by religion and region. Communal violence had weakened society. National unity was needed to rebuild the country. It ensured peace and stability.

questions.question: How did the leaders try to promote peace after partition?
questions.answer: Leaders visited riot areas and appealed for harmony. Relief camps were set up. Gandhiji fasted to stop violence. Efforts were made to reduce hatred.

questions.question: What was the condition of Indian economy in 1947?
questions.answer: The economy was very weak after independence. Industries were less developed. There was shortage of food. Poverty was widespread in the country.

questions.question: What was the importance of democracy in independent India?
questions.answer: Democracy gave people the right to choose their government. It ensured equality and freedom. Everyone could express their views. It strengthened the nation.

questions.question: Why did some princely states oppose joining India?
questions.answer: Some rulers wanted to remain independent. Some feared losing power. Others wanted to join Pakistan. This created problems for integration.

questions.question: What was the role of the army in integrating states?
questions.answer: The army was used in some difficult cases. It helped in merging Hyderabad and Junagadh. It protected national unity. It ensured peace in troubled regions.

questions.question: What was the importance of the Instrument of Accession?
questions.answer: It legally united princely states with India. Rulers signed this document. It avoided violence in most cases. It helped build a united nation.

questions.question: What was the biggest challenge faced by India in 1947?
questions.answer: The biggest challenge was partition violence. Millions became homeless. There was loss of life and property. Unity of the country was threatened.

questions.question: Why is communal harmony important?
questions.answer: Communal harmony keeps society peaceful. It reduces hatred between religions. It helps in national development. It strengthens unity.

questions.question: What role did Gandhiji play in refugee rehabilitation?
questions.answer: Gandhiji visited refugee camps. He listened to their problems. He encouraged peace and tolerance. His words gave hope to suffering people.

questions.question: What happened to Punjab during partition?
questions.answer: Punjab was divided between India and Pakistan. There were severe riots. Millions migrated from both sides. Many families were destroyed.

questions.question: What was the importance of unity after independence?
questions.answer: Unity helped India recover from violence. It strengthened national spirit. It reduced regional conflicts. It was necessary for progress.

questions.question: How were refugee children affected?
questions.answer: Many children lost their parents. They were separated from families. They lived in camps without education. Their lives became very difficult.

questions.question: Why was food shortage a serious problem?
questions.answer: Partition disrupted agriculture. Many farmers migrated. Crops were destroyed in riots. This created food scarcity in many regions.

questions.question: What was the dream of leaders after independence?
questions.answer: They wanted a strong and united India. They dreamed of peace and equality. They wanted development and education for all. They aimed to remove poverty.

questions.question: Why is 26 January celebrated as Republic Day?
questions.answer: On 26 January 1950 India adopted its Constitution. The country became a republic. It gave fundamental rights to citizens. It is a national festival.

questions.question: How did partition change the lives of people?
questions.answer: People lost homes and property. Families were divided. They had to start new lives. It caused pain and suffering.

questions.question: What lesson do we learn from the partition of India?
questions.answer: Partition teaches the value of unity. It shows the dangers of communal hatred. It reminds us to live peacefully. It encourages brotherhood.

questions.question: What was the emotional impact of independence on Indians?
questions.answer: Independence filled people with joy and pride. They felt free after long years of struggle. Many celebrated the end of British rule. It also brought hope for a better future.

questions.question: Why did the leaders emphasise secularism?
questions.answer: India has people of many religions. Secularism ensures equal respect to all religions. It prevents discrimination. It helps maintain peace in society.

questions.question: What was the importance of Jawaharlal Nehru’s speech on independence day?
questions.answer: Nehru delivered the famous Tryst with Destiny speech. It inspired the nation. It marked the beginning of a new era. It gave people hope and confidence.

questions.question: Why were relief camps important after partition?
questions.answer: Relief camps provided shelter to refugees. They gave food, clothes and medicines. They helped people who lost everything. They supported rehabilitation.

questions.question: What was the condition of women refugees?
questions.answer: Women suffered greatly during partition. Many lost their families. They faced violence and insecurity. Relief camps tried to protect them.

questions.question: Why was education important for rebuilding India?
questions.answer: Education helps people gain knowledge and skills. It creates responsible citizens. It reduces poverty. It is necessary for national development.

questions.question: What was the importance of law and order after independence?
questions.answer: Law and order was needed to stop violence. It protected citizens. It ensured peace in cities and villages. It helped restore normal life.

questions.question: How did independence change the political system?
questions.answer: British rule ended in 1947. India adopted democracy. People elected their leaders. Power came into the hands of Indians.

questions.question: What was the role of volunteers in refugee camps?
questions.answer: Volunteers helped distribute food and clothes. They took care of sick people. They supported children and women. Their service reduced suffering.

questions.question: Why is unity called the strength of India?
questions.answer: India has many languages and religions. Unity keeps the nation together. It helps in development. It protects the country from division.

questions.question: What was the importance of the Indian Constitution?
questions.answer: The Constitution gives fundamental rights. It guides the government. It ensures justice and equality. It is the backbone of democracy.

questions.question: Why did refugees need employment?
questions.answer: Refugees lost their homes and jobs. They needed income to survive. Employment helped them rebuild their lives. It restored dignity.

questions.question: What was the role of the press after independence?
questions.answer: The press spread awareness among people. It reported problems of refugees. It supported unity and democracy. It acted as the voice of citizens.

questions.question: Why is communal harmony essential in a democracy?
questions.answer: Democracy respects all religions. Communal harmony avoids conflict. It promotes peace and cooperation. It strengthens the nation.

questions.question: How did migration affect villages and towns?
questions.answer: Many villages became empty. Towns became overcrowded. Housing and food problems increased. Life became difficult for people.

questions.question: What was the responsibility of citizens after independence?
questions.answer: Citizens had to follow laws. They had to work for unity. They were expected to contribute to development. Democracy depended on them.

questions.question: Why was national integration a priority?
questions.answer: The nation was divided after partition. Violence had weakened society. Integration helped unite people. It ensured long-term peace.

questions.question: What was the importance of economic planning?
questions.answer: Economic planning helped develop industries. It reduced poverty. It improved living standards. It supported national growth.

questions.question: How did independence inspire youth?
questions.answer: Youth felt proud to be free citizens. They dreamed of a better India. They wanted education and jobs. They became active in nation building.

questions.question: What is the message of the chapter India Gains Independence?
questions.answer: The chapter teaches the value of freedom. It highlights unity and sacrifice. It warns against communal hatred. It inspires patriotism.

questions.question: Why did the leaders appeal for peace after partition?
questions.answer: Violence had spread across many regions. Thousands of people were killed. Leaders wanted to stop bloodshed. They encouraged people to live peacefully.

questions.question: What was the impact of riots on ordinary citizens?
questions.answer: People lost homes and property. Many families were separated. Fear spread everywhere. Normal life was disturbed.

questions.question: Why were trains important for refugees?
questions.answer: Trains helped people migrate quickly. They carried families to safer places. Many travelled long distances. They were the main means of transport.

questions.question: How did farmers suffer during partition?
questions.answer: Many farmers left their lands. Crops were destroyed. Livestock was lost. Their income sources vanished.

questions.question: What was the condition of cities after independence?
questions.answer: Cities were overcrowded with refugees. Housing was insufficient. Food and water were limited. Authorities struggled to manage the situation.

questions.question: Why did families migrate to unknown places?
questions.answer: People feared violence in their areas. They wanted safety. Many followed relatives. They had no choice but to leave.

questions.question: What was the role of social workers during refugee crisis?
questions.answer: Social workers helped distribute food. They took care of children and elderly. They provided emotional support. Their service reduced pain.

questions.question: Why was shelter a major problem for refugees?
questions.answer: Millions lost their houses. Camps were overcrowded. There were not enough buildings. Many lived in temporary huts.

questions.question: How did independence affect rural life?
questions.answer: Villages were disturbed by migration. Labour shortage occurred. Agriculture suffered. People slowly returned to rebuild their lives.

questions.question: Why was rebuilding India a difficult task?
questions.answer: The country was poor. Violence had destroyed peace. There were shortages of resources. Unity had to be restored.

questions.question: What was the importance of self-reliance after independence?
questions.answer: India had to depend on its own resources. Industries needed development. People had to work hard. Self-reliance ensured progress.

questions.question: Why did many people feel insecure after 1947?
questions.answer: Violence had shaken their confidence. Families were separated. Jobs were uncertain. Fear was still in minds.

questions.question: What was the role of teachers after independence?
questions.answer: Teachers educated children. They spread patriotic values. They guided youth for nation building. They helped rebuild society.

questions.question: How did independence encourage women?
questions.answer: Women got equal rights. They joined education and jobs. They participated in social work. Independence gave them confidence.

questions.question: Why was employment generation important?
questions.answer: People needed income to survive. Refugees had lost everything. Jobs restored dignity. Employment helped rebuild the economy.

questions.question: What was the significance of freedom for future generations?
questions.answer: Freedom gave opportunities. Children could dream big. They could choose careers freely. It ensured a bright future.

questions.question: Why is patriotism important in independent India?
questions.answer: Patriotism creates love for the nation. It unites people. It inspires service to the country. It protects national unity.

questions.question: What was the psychological impact of partition?
questions.answer: People felt trauma and fear. They lost trust in neighbours. Pain remained for years. It deeply affected minds.

questions.question: How did leaders motivate the nation after independence?
questions.answer: They gave inspiring speeches. They appealed for unity. They started development plans. They encouraged hard work.

questions.question: Why was peace essential for progress?
questions.answer: Without peace development is impossible. Violence destroys resources. Harmony helps cooperation. Peace builds a strong nation.

questions.question: How did independence change the identity of Indians?
questions.answer: They became citizens of a free nation. They felt proud. Their confidence increased. They believed in self-rule.

questions.question: Why is history of independence important for students?
questions.answer: It teaches sacrifice. It inspires patriotism. It warns against division. It builds respect for freedom.

questions.question: What was the importance of unity among states?
questions.answer: Unity avoided conflicts. It strengthened administration. It created one nation. It supported development.

questions.question: How did people celebrate independence?
questions.answer: They hoisted flags. They sang patriotic songs. They organised functions. They expressed joy.

questions.question: Why was national rebuilding slow after 1947?
questions.answer: Resources were limited. Refugee problems were huge. Violence disturbed progress. It took time to recover.

questions.question: How did independence affect education system?
questions.answer: New schools were opened. Education was expanded. Focus was on national values. Literacy slowly increased.

questions.question: Why was industrial development necessary?
questions.answer: Industries created jobs. They reduced poverty. They increased production. They strengthened the economy.

questions.question: What was the dream of freedom fighters?
questions.answer: They wanted a free and united India. They dreamed of equality. They wished for peace. They worked for justice.

questions.question: How did independence bring hope to people?
questions.answer: It ended foreign rule. People felt confident. They dreamed of better life. It filled hearts with optimism.

questions.question: What is the main lesson from India’s independence?
questions.answer: Freedom is precious. Unity is strength. Hatred destroys peace. Cooperation builds the nation.
